articles.headline: Making Home a Safer Place, Affordably
articles.snippet: If older people choose to remain in houses where they are comfortable, there are many ways to shore up their homes’ safety.
articles.abstract: If older people choose to remain in houses where they are comfortable, there are many ways to shore up their homes’ safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stay put or sell?

articles.headline: A Fearless Activist in a Land of Thugs
articles.snippet: Natalya Estemirova was a leading human rights investigator in the Caucasus.
articles.abstract: Natalya Estemirova was a leading human rights investigator in the Caucasus.
articles.lead_paragraph: NATALYA ESTEMIROVA is gone now. Her executioners forced her into a car in front of her home in Chechnya and sped away with her on Wednesday morning. She managed to shout that she was being kidnapped, her last known words documenting the beginning of the crimes against her, just as she had documented crimes against uncountable others.

articles.headline: Last Man Standing
articles.snippet: Best Buy is focusing on fast-growing products like mobile phones and low-cost laptops and moving away from CDs and DVDs.
articles.abstract: Best Buy is focusing on fast-growing products like mobile phones and low-cost laptops and moving away from CDs and DVDs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Brian Pollett, a music-loving college student here, headed into a local Best Buy store last month to pick up some Bose headphones. Why Best Buy? Because he didn’t want to shop online and wait for delivery  and Best Buy’s retail competitors are all out of business.

articles.headline: Amazon Erases Orwell Books From Kindle
articles.snippet: An Amazon spokesman said that “1984” and “Animal Farm” were added to the Kindle store by a company that did not have rights to them, using a self-service function.
articles.abstract: An Amazon spokesman said that “1984” and “Animal Farm” were added to the Kindle store by a company that did not have rights to them, using a self-service function.
articles.lead_paragraph: In George Orwell’s “1984,” government censors erase all traces of news articles embarrassing to Big Brother by sending them down an incineration chute called the “memory hole.”

articles.headline: Walter Cronkite, 92, Dies; Trusted Voice of TV News
articles.snippet: Mr. Cronkite guided viewers with such plain-spoken grace that he was called the most trusted man in America.
articles.abstract: Mr. Cronkite guided viewers with such plain-spoken grace that he was called the most trusted man in America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walter Cronkite, who pioneered and then mastered the role of television news anchorman with such plain-spoken grace that he was called the most trusted man in America, died Friday at his home in New York. He was 92.

articles.headline: Looking Back in Anger at the Crisis
articles.snippet: If the Bank of America hearings show anything, it is that Congress is taking away all the wrong lessons from the crisis.
articles.abstract: If the Bank of America hearings show anything, it is that Congress is taking away all the wrong lessons from the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Did they first bring up the bailout to you, or did you bring it up to them?” asked Congressman Edolphus Towns, the chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

articles.headline: Converting an I.R.A. Into a Roth? How’s Your Crystal Ball?
articles.snippet: Tax laws change, making the decision to turn a regular individual retirement account into a Roth potentially difficult.
articles.abstract: Tax laws change, making the decision to turn a regular individual retirement account into a Roth potentially difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’ll be hearing a lot in the next six months about Roth Individual Retirement Accounts  but not as much as you should about a long-term threat that hangs over them.

articles.headline: A New Enforcer in Buildings, the Energy Inspector
articles.snippet: Building inefficient homes locks in waste for decades, but construction codes for many states and cities are weak.
articles.abstract: Building inefficient homes locks in waste for decades, but construction codes for many states and cities are weak.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.  Peering behind a bathtub in a newly built house, an inspector, John Umphress, spotted a big gap in the wall insulation. “Somebody took a lunch break!” he complained to the builder, who sheepishly agreed to patch the hole.

articles.headline: Drivers and Legislators Dismiss Cellphone Risks
articles.snippet: Research shows the dangers of distracted driving. But drivers increasingly talk and text, and state legislators have done almost nothing about it.
articles.abstract: Research shows the dangers of distracted driving. But drivers increasingly talk and text, and state legislators have done almost nothing about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY  On his 15th birthday, Christopher Hill got his first cellphone. For his 16th, he was given a used red Ford Ranger pickup, a source of pride he washed every week.

articles.headline: Iranian Critic Quotes Khomeini Principles
articles.snippet: Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a former president, has cast himself in a new light: as a player with the authority to interpret Iran’s ideals.
articles.abstract: Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a former president, has cast himself in a new light: as a player with the authority to interpret Iran’s ideals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  During his decades in Iranian politics, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani has been praised as a pragmatist, criticized as spineless, accused of corruption and dismissed as a has-been.

articles.headline: Defying Slump, 13 States Insure More Children
articles.snippet: Despite budgets ravaged by the recession, at least 13 states have invested millions to cover 250,000 more children with subsidized government health insurance.
articles.abstract: Despite budgets ravaged by the recession, at least 13 states have invested millions to cover 250,000 more children with subsidized government health insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite budgets ravaged by the recession, at least 13 states have invested millions of dollars this year to cover 250,000 more children with subsidized government health insurance.

articles.headline: A Matter of Opinion?
articles.snippet: Floyd Abrams, the most famous First Amendment lawyer in the country, might surprise his admirers with his representation of a company regarded as Part of the Problem in the economic meltdown.
articles.abstract: Floyd Abrams, the most famous First Amendment lawyer in the country, might surprise his admirers with his representation of a company regarded as Part of the Problem in the economic meltdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: THERE will be admirers of Floyd Abrams, the most famous First Amendment lawyer in the country, who are surprised to learn that he represents a corporation widely regarded as Part of the Problem in the economic meltdown. These people are likely to have a passing familiarity with Mr. Abrams’s four-decade career and think of him as a tribune of free speech and a defender of underdogs.

articles.headline: In Washington, One Bank Chief Still Holds Sway
articles.snippet: With the financial crisis, Jamie Dimon, the head of JPMorgan Chase, has become more politically engaged and in the process, the most credible voice of a discredited industry.
articles.abstract: With the financial crisis, Jamie Dimon, the head of JPMorgan Chase, has become more politically engaged and in the process, the most credible voice of a discredited industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Jamie Dimon, the head of JPMorgan Chase, will hold a meeting of his board here in the nation’s capital for the first time on Monday, with a special guest expected: the White House chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Louise Story

articles.headline: Tightening Belts? She’s the Expert
articles.snippet: Diane von Furstenberg and the wrap dress she created have survived the whims of fashion.
articles.abstract: Diane von Furstenberg and the wrap dress she created have survived the whims of fashion.
articles.lead_paragraph: A SOAKING June rain is blowing sideways through the meatpacking district of Manhattan, pummeling umbrellas and already grim retail sales. Above the cobblestone streets, in her Balinese-inspired living room-cum-office, Diane von Furstenberg is stretched like a cat on the couch, coolly gazing beyond the Buddha statues and glass terrace doors at the rain.

articles.headline: CIT Is Said to Obtain Loan to Avert Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The lender approved a deal with major bondholders to help it avert a bankruptcy filing through a $3 billion emergency loan, people briefed on the matter said.
articles.abstract: The lender approved a deal with major bondholders to help it avert a bankruptcy filing through a $3 billion emergency loan, people briefed on the matter said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Directors of the CIT Group, one of the nation’s leading lenders to small and midsize businesses, approved a deal Sunday evening with some of the bank’s major bondholders to help it avert a bankruptcy filing through a $3 billion emergency loan, according to people briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Pentagon Seeks to Overhaul Prisons in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: A plan to overhaul the troubled U.S.-run prison at Bagram Air Base and other facilities was prompted by worries about militant recruiting in the prisons.
articles.abstract: A plan to overhaul the troubled U.S.-run prison at Bagram Air Base and other facilities was prompted by worries about militant recruiting in the prisons.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGRAM AIR BASE, Afghanistan  A sweeping United States military review calls for overhauling the troubled American-run prison here as well as the entire Afghan jail and judicial systems, a reaction to worries that abuses and militant recruiting within the prisons are helping to strengthen the Taliban.

articles.headline: Why Japan’s Cellphones Haven’t Gone Global
articles.snippet: Japanese handset makers’ rush to innovation in the last 15 years has put them so far ahead they can’t find a niche to expand outside their networks.
articles.abstract: Japanese handset makers’ rush to innovation in the last 15 years has put them so far ahead they can’t find a niche to expand outside their networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  At first glance, Japanese cellphones are a gadget lover’s dream: ready for Internet and e-mail, they double as credit cards, boarding passes and even body-fat calculators.

articles.headline: In India, New Life for Comic Books as TV Cartoons
articles.snippet: A former consultant hopes his company can tell traditional stories from India to a new generation of children.
articles.abstract: A former consultant hopes his company can tell traditional stories from India to a new generation of children.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  Like many Indians who came of age in the 1980s, Samir Patil grew up on the comic books published by Amar Chitra Katha. Made up of Indian-style Aesop’s fables, religious parables and biographies of historical figures, they taught him about the great, and lesser-known, stories of India in a didactic format meant for young audiences.

articles.headline: Across U.S., ESPN Aims to Be the Home Team
articles.snippet: After a successful test run in Chicago, ESPN is planning to launch local sports Web sites in three additional cities.
articles.abstract: After a successful test run in Chicago, ESPN is planning to launch local sports Web sites in three additional cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Not content with being a sports colossus with broadcasts in 200 countries, ESPN is taking aim at hometown sports coverage, threatening one of the last strongholds of local newspapers and television stations.

articles.headline: Subprime Brokers Back as Dubious Loan Fixers
articles.snippet: Some of the very people who made a killing in subprime mortgages are now offering loan modifications for desperate homeowners.
articles.abstract: Some of the very people who made a killing in subprime mortgages are now offering loan modifications for desperate homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  From the ninth floor of a downtown office building on Wilshire Boulevard, Jack Soussana delivered staggering numbers of mortgages to homeowners during the real estate boom, amassing a fortune.

articles.headline: Obama Aide Declines Visit to Bank Board
articles.snippet: A late decision from Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, is meant to avoid a situation that could be viewed as a conflict of interest.
articles.abstract: A late decision from Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, is meant to avoid a situation that could be viewed as a conflict of interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The White House chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, has decided not to speak to the board of JPMorgan Chase when it meets here on Monday, he said Sunday after considering the invitation for several days.

articles.headline: South Africa Is Seen to Lag in H.I.V. Fight
articles.snippet: The government does not provide circumcision to help fight the disease or educate the public about its benefits.
articles.abstract: The government does not provide circumcision to help fight the disease or educate the public about its benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORANGE FARM, South Africa  Young men have flocked by the thousands to this clinic for circumcisions, the only one of its kind in South Africa. Each of them lies down on one of seven closely spaced surgical tables, his privacy shielded only by a green curtain.

articles.headline: Conflicting Priorities Endanger High-Tech Army Program
articles.snippet: Future Combat Systems, a $160 billion project to have unmanned vehicles act as spies on enemy targets, is unlikely to come to fruition.
articles.abstract: Future Combat Systems, a $160 billion project to have unmanned vehicles act as spies on enemy targets, is unlikely to come to fruition.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Army hatched a plan a decade ago for a new approach to fighting ground wars. Called Future Combat Systems, it was an ambitious project to develop networks of high-tech vehicles, drones and robotic sensors to act as frontline spies on enemy targets.

articles.headline: Jackson Assets Draw the Gaze of Wall Street
articles.snippet: Big financial firms have made inquiries into buying the Michael Jackson estate’s 50 percent share of Sony/ATV Music Publishing.
articles.abstract: Big financial firms have made inquiries into buying the Michael Jackson estate’s 50 percent share of Sony/ATV Music Publishing.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the world sorts through the pieces of Michael Jackson’s life one month after his death, so, too, does Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Suspect Stirs Mumbai Court by Confessing
articles.snippet: The only survivor among the team of gunmen who killed more than 160 people in November offered a dramatic and unexpected confession.
articles.abstract: The only survivor among the team of gunmen who killed more than 160 people in November offered a dramatic and unexpected confession.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  The sole surviving gunman of the deadly rampage in Mumbai unexpectedly confessed in court here on Monday, adding his voice, matter-of-fact even as he spoke of opening fire into crowds, to what may be the most well-documented terrorist attack anywhere.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Lydia Polgreen

articles.headline: Markets, Buoyed by Leading Indicators, Gain Momentum
articles.snippet: Upbeat investors welcomed reports that the CIT Group was close to securing enough financing to avoid bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: Upbeat investors welcomed reports that the CIT Group was close to securing enough financing to avoid bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most Americans are still waiting for this painful recession to end. But on Wall Street, new signs that the economy just may be turning heartened investors on Monday.
